abstract.p: Joseph Nogee letter holds Bernard Holland's June 18 article comparing music with painting overlooks time required for public to absorb what artist seeks to communicate (S)

block.p: Bernard Holland's comparison of music and painting overlooks an important difference from the perspective of the consumer (or public): the time required to absorb what the artist seeks to communicate. With paintings it requires seconds or minutes. A musical composition, however, takes much longer, sometimes over an hour. That in part explains why the public is so much less tolerant of contemporary music than of contemporary art. If the painting offends, a viewer can simply move on to another painting or leave the museum altogether. The concertgoer confronted with atonality or serialism is held prisoner until the performance ends.
